natural problem: What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\log_2(\log_3(\log_4x))$?
natural solution: In order for the given function to have a real value, $\log_3(\log_4x)>0$ (since the logarithm of only any positive number is real). In order for the last inequality to be true, $\log_4x>1$ (since the logarithm of only any number greater than 1 is greater than 0).
The last inequality is true only if $x>4^1$, so $x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x > 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = log 2 (log 3 (log 4 x))"
shows  "Domain f = {x. x > 4}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\log_2(\log_3(\log_4x))$? The final Answer is (4, \infty)
 ### Proof
 In order for the given function to have a real value, $\log_3(\log_4x)>0$ (since the logarithm of only any positive number is real). In order for the last inequality to be true, $\log_4x>1$ (since the logarithm of only any number greater than 1 is greater than 0).
 The last inequality is true only if $x>4^1$, so $x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x > 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = log 2 (log 3 (log 4 x))"
shows  "Domain f = {x. x > 4}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Define a function $f(x) = \log_2 (\log_3 (\log_4 x))$ for all $x$ greater than $4$. What is the domain of this function? The domain of the function is all real numbers greater than $4$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x > 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = log 2 (log 3 (log 4 x))"
shows  "x \<in> {4<..}"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\log_2(\log_3(\log_4x))$? The final Answer is (4, \infty)
 ### Proof
 In order for the given function to have a real value, $\log_3(\log_4x)>0$ (since the logarithm of only any positive number is real). In order for the last inequality to be true, $\log_4x>1$ (since the logarithm of only any number greater than 1 is greater than 0).
 The last inequality is true only if $x>4^1$, so $x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x > 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = log 2 (log 3 (log 4 x))"
shows  "x \<in> {4<..}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Let $f$ be a bijective function. If $f(x) = log_2(log_3(log_4(x)))$ for all $x > 4$, find the set of all values of $x$ that satisfy this condition. The final answer is all $x$ such that $x > 4$.

 *)

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = log 2 (log 3 (log 4 x))"
shows  "4 < x"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\log_2(\log_3(\log_4x))$? The final Answer is (4, \infty)
 ### Proof
 In order for the given function to have a real value, $\log_3(\log_4x)>0$ (since the logarithm of only any positive number is real). In order for the last inequality to be true, $\log_4x>1$ (since the logarithm of only any number greater than 1 is greater than 0).
 The last inequality is true only if $x>4^1$, so $x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.
 *)

fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = log 2 (log 3 (log 4 x))"
shows  "4 < x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the smallest real number $x$ for which the triple nested logarithm $log_2(log_3(log_4(x)))$ is defined. The final answer is that $x$ must be strictly greater than $4$.
